page.title: 11Mining in Blackridge
page.content: The only trace of the pits are the memories of the workers alive today, the bings and{old railway}tracks. The bings are spread all around {Blackridge. }But at the moment cranes and trucks are removing the bings to nearby{power stations. }These bings are made up from silt from the settling ponds. Silt is coal dust. The silt goes into ponds and the water dries and that's how the bings are formed. There were six different pits in Blackridge at one time. The names of these pits were Westrigg, Blackridge New Pit No3, Standhill, Woodend, Netherton Mine and Blairmuckhill. Once a pit shut down the miners would be transferred to another pit. The only other proof is the old miners' cottages. {Westcraigs}is a row of many old cottages.
